title:
Personalized graph feature-based multi-omics data integration for cancer
  subtype identification
abstract:
Cancer is a highly heterogeneous disease with significant variability in
molecular features and clinical outcomes, making diagnosis and treatment
challenging. In recent years, high-throughput omic technologies have
facilitated the discovery of mechanisms underlying various cancer subtypes by
providing diverse omics data, such as gene expression, DNA methylation, and
miRNA expression. However, the complexity and heterogeneity of multi-omics data
present significant challenges for their integration in exploring cancer
subtypes. Various methods have been proposed to address these challenges. In
this paper, we propose a novel and straightforward approach for identifying
cancer subtypes by integrating patient-specific subnetworks features from
different omics data. We construct patient-specific induced subnetwork using a
random walk with restart algorithm from patient similarity networks (PSNs) and
compute nine structural properties that capture essential network topology.
These features are integrated across the three omic datasets to form
comprehensive patient profiles. K-means clustering is then applied for cancer
subtype identification. We evaluate our approach on five cancer datasets,
including breast invasive carcinoma, colon adenocarcinoma, glioblastoma
multiforme, kidney renal clear cell carcinoma, and lung squamous cell
carcinoma, for three different omic data types. The evaluation shows that our
method produces promising and effective results, demonstrating competitive or
superior performance compared to existing methods and underscoring its
potential for advancing personalized cancer diagnosis and treatment.
